item.title: Trump Plays Down Iran-Israel Truce as He Leaves G-7 Early
item.description: US President Donald Trump left the Group of Seven leaders meeting in Canada early to deal with the Israel-Iran conflict, playing down the prospects of a ceasefire in favor of “a real end.”
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Stephanie Lai, Arsalan Shahla

item.title: Pakistan’s Army Chief Makes First US Trip After India Clashes
item.description: Pakistan’s military said its army chief is in the US on an official visit, just weeks after President Donald Trump said he had brokered a ceasefire between Islamabad and New Delhi following intense clashes.
item.dc:creator: Kamran Haider, Michal Kubala

media:content.media:description: Asim Munir

item.title: Trump, Ishiba Fail to Reach Trade Deal at G-7 Summit
item.description: US President Donald Trump and Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba failed to reach an agreement on a trade package on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit, an outcome that leaves the Asian nation inching closer to a possible recession as the pain of US tariffs hits its economy.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami, Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba at the Group of Seven (G7) Summit in Kananaskis, Alberta, Canada, on June 16.

item.title: Trump Says He Wants a ‘Real End,’ Not Just Ceasefire in Iran
item.description: US President Donald Trump said his early departure from the Group of Seven leaders meeting in Canada has “nothing to do” with working on a ceasefire between Israel and Iran, adding that his reason is “much bigger than that.”
item.dc:creator: Derek Wallbank, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump waves after leaving the G7 Leaders’ Summit early on June 16.

item.title: Trump’s Snub to G-7 Bodes Ill for NATO Summit
item.description: The US president’s early departure highlighted his contempt for the forum, once a place where like-minded allies would discuss international crises
item.dc:creator: Flavia Krause-Jackson

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump departs following a group photo during the G7 Leaders' Summit in Canada on June 16. Photographer: Pool/Getty Images

item.title: Harvard Wins Reprieve, SALT Stalls: Tax Bill Winners and Losers
item.description: US businesses and wealthy universities scored major wins in the Senate Republicans’ version of President Donald Trump’s tax bill, while low-income Americans and clean energy providers are poised to be hit the hardest.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz

media:content.media:description: Dunster House on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts

item.title: Turkey Accelerates Missile Production Amid Fears of Wider War
item.description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan ordered officials to increase the production of medium and long-range missiles in light of the Israel-Iran conflict, an acceleration of plans to develop a strong home-grown industry.
item.dc:creator: Selcan Hacaoglu, Firat Kozok

media:content.media:description: A Turkish ‘Tayfun’ missile test.

item.title: Mali to Take Control of Key Barrick Gold Mine for Six Months
item.description: A Malian court ruled that Barrick Mining Corp.’s Loulo-Gounkoto gold mining complex should be placed under provisional administration for six months, handing control of one of the Canadian company’s biggest operations to state-appointed management.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije, Diakaridia Dembele, Jacob Lorinc

media:content.media:description: Dumper trucks collect rock ore from from the digging floor in a section of the Loulo-Gounkoto gold mining complex. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

item.title: Wind, Solar Credits Set to End Early in Senate GOP Tax Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans released a bill that would end tax credits for wind and solar earlier than for other sources, and make only modest changes to most other incentives, dashing hopes of those seeking relief from major cuts passed by the House.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Contractors install SunRun solar panels on the roof of a home in San Jose, California, U.S., on Monday, Feb. 7, 2022. California regulators are delaying a vote on a controversial proposal to slash incentives for home solar systems as they consider revamping the measure.

item.title: Putin’s Aide Shoigu Visits Pyongyang Again on ‘Special Mission’
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin’s top security aide Sergei Shoigu made his third visit to North Korea in as many months according to Tass, in a sign of Moscow’s deepening embrace of North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: Sergei Shoigu Photographer: Yasuyoshi Chiba/Getty Images

item.title: Russian Strikes Pound Kyiv as Trump Goes Slow on Sanctions
item.description: Russian air strikes killed at least 14 people in Kyiv in what President Volodymyr Zelenskiy described as “one of the most horrific attacks” as multiple locations in the Ukrainian capital were struck by drones and missiles or hit by debris.
item.dc:creator: Kateryna Chursina

media:content.media:description: Rescuers conduct a search and rescue work in a damaged residential building following the Russian missile strike in Kyiv on June 17.

item.title: El éxodo cubano toma un nuevo rumbo: adiós Miami, hola Curitiba
item.description: La ciudad, ubicada en el corazón agrícola de Brasil, se está convirtiendo en un nuevo destino a medida que EE.UU. da la espalda a quienes huyen de la isla.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Rosati, Meg Lopes

media:content.media:description: Curitiba, Brazil is known for its lush green parks and has seen waves of foreigners arriving over the past decade and a half.

item.title: Cubans Shut Out by Trump Are Ditching Miami for Brazil’s Deep South
item.description: Curitiba, the capital of a wealthy agricultural state, is becoming a new favored destination as the US turns its back on those fleeing the communist island
item.dc:creator: Andrew Rosati, Meg Lopes

media:content.media:description: Curitiba, Brazil, has seen waves of foreigners arrive over the years including Haitians, Venezuelans and now Cubans.

item.title: South Korea’s Lee Wants Trade Deal with US Before July Deadline
item.description: South Korea’s President Lee Jae-myung hopes to clinch a trade agreement with the US ahead of a looming July deadline, according to his nominee for prime minister, after a high-stakes meeting with Donald Trump was called off at the last minute.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung

item.title: China Suggests US Should Help Ease Tensions Between Israel, Iran
item.description: China suggested the US use its influence with Israel to stop the conflict with Iran from spilling over, a sign Beijing is becoming increasingly concerned about the stability of a region it relies on for energy supplies.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Qianwei Zhang

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises from the site of a reported Israeli strike on an Iranian state media in Tehran, on June 16. Photographer: MINA/Getty Images

item.title: Modi Misses Chance to Push for US Trade Deal as Trump Leaves G-7
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi had no opportunity to push for a US trade deal with Donald Trump after the American president left the Group of Seven leaders’ summit early, a potential setback for New Delhi as recent tariff negotiations hit hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, center, arrives at Calgary Airport on June 16. Photographer: Dave Chidley/Getty Images

item.title: EU Refuses China Meetings Over Trade Spat Before Leaders Summit
item.description: The European Union is refusing to hold an economic meeting with China due to a lack of progress on trade disputes, underscoring widening tensions between the two sides even as Beijing tries to warm ties.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, James Mayger

item.title: China’s Consumer Rush for Subsidies Overloads Stimulus Program
item.description: China is testing the limits of what its consumer stimulus can accomplish by subsidizing purchases of select goods, fueling a shopping spree that boosted retail sales growth to the strongest in more than a year but threatening to overwhelm authorities even in the richest regions.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Fran Wang

media:content.media:description: Customers at an electronics retail store in Beijing.

item.title: Pakistan, US Target Early Trade Deal After High-Level Discussion
item.description: Pakistan and US officials held high-level tariff talks on Monday and aim to finalize a trade agreement at the earliest, Islamabad said in a statement, as the South Asian nation pushes for relief from retaliatory duties imposed by President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Kamran Haider, Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the port of Houston in Seabrook, Texas.

item.title: Irish State Exits AIB, Putting Bank Into Private Ownership
item.description: The Irish state has disposed of the remainder of its shareholding in AIB Group plc, putting the bank into private ownership.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: An Allied Irish Banks branch in Dublin.

item.title: Greece Steps Up Defense Push With Deal for Ammunition Production
item.description: Greece’s Hellenic Defense systems and Czechoslovak Group AS have agreed to jointly produce ammunition, in a bid to bolster Europe’s weapons capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Sotiris Nikas

media:content.media:description: An Excalibur Army T-72 main battle tank in the factory of the Czechoslovak Group AS (CSG) unit in Sternberk, Czech Republic.

item.title: Reeves Weighs Reversing Non-Dom Inheritance Tax Changes, FT Says
item.description: Rachel Reeves is considering reversing a decision to charge inheritance tax on the overseas assets of non-doms, according to the Financial Times.
item.dc:creator: Leonard Kehnscherper

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves, UK chancellor of the exchequer, outside 11 Downing Street ahead of the presentation of the spending review in London, UK, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Reeves will defend her fiscal choices and trumpet billions of pounds of infrastructure investment in the UK spending review on Wednesday, as Keir Starmer's government seeks to regain momentum after a faltering first year in power. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Israel’s Air Shield Is Tested Like Never Before as Iran Fires Ballistic Missiles
item.description: As Iran fires masses of ballistic missiles, Israel’s vaunted air defenses are being tested like never before.
item.dc:creator: Paul Wallace, Galit Altstein

item.title: Trump Tax Bill to Boost Biden’s Chip Tax Credit to 30%
item.description: The Senate’s draft tax bill calls for increasing an investment credit for semiconductor manufacturers, a potential boon for chipmakers that the Trump administration is urging to increase the size of their US projects.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz, Mackenzie Hawkins

media:content.media:description: A bare wafer stacker sorts silicon wafers in Building 51 at Micron Technology Inc. headquarters in Boise, Idaho, US, on Monday, June 10, 2024. The US announced in April its plans to award Micron Technology Inc. $6.1 billion in grants and as much as $7.5 billion in loans to help the memory-chip maker build new American factories, rounding out a slew of major federal awards for advanced semiconductor manufacturing.

item.title: G-7 Leaders Seek ‘Resolution’ of Iranian Crisis in Statement
item.description: The Group of Seven leaders pushed for a de-escalation in the Middle East but didn’t call for an immediate end to the conflict between Israel and Iran in a statement that also affirmed Israel’s right to defend itself.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: (L/R) European Council President António Costa, Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba, Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, French President Emmanuel Macron, Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney, US President Donald Trump, British Prime Minister Keir Starmer, German Chancellor Friedrich Merz and European Union President Ursula von der Leyen pose for a family photo during the Group of Seven (G7) Summit at the Kananaskis Country Golf Course in Kananaskis, Alberta, Canada on June 16, 2025. (Photo by Brendan SMIALOWSKI / AFP) (Photo by BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Leaves G-7 Summit Early as Israel-Iran Tension Spikes
item.description: President Donald Trump’s hasty exit from the Group of Seven conference in Canada deepened questions about his promise to bring peace to an increasingly violent world and added fresh evidence of his skepticism toward the institutions that have long underpinned US diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump at the G-7 Summit on June 16.

item.title: Britain's Housing Splurge Is Long Overdue
item.description: The Labour government’s plan to boost spending on affordable homes has the potential to pay for itself in wider economic benefits.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brooker

media:content.media:description: ASHFORD, KENT - JULY 11: Construction work takes place on a short-term pod housing project for the homeless at Henwood Industrial Estate on July 11, 2024 in Ashford, Kent. The project, in which 23 pods will provide temporary accommodation to people facing homelessness, is scheduled to be completed in September with its first residents moving in soon thereafter. The project was spearheaded by Ashford Borough Council with additional funding coming from the national government. (Photo by Chris J Ratcliffe/Getty Images)

item.title: Australian PM’s Meeting With Trump Scrapped After G-7 Departure
item.description: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese’s first in-person meeting with Donald Trump was canceled after the president decided to leave a Group of Seven summit early to focus on the conflict between Israel and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Michael Heath

media:content.media:description: Anthony Albanese Photographer: Hilary Wardhaugh/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Set to Depart G-7 Early as Israel-Iran Tension Spikes
item.description: President Donald Trump is set to depart the Group of Seven leaders’ summit in Canada a day early, after warning residents of Tehran to evacuate the city as Israel continued to bombard Iran in a bid to disable its nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Stephanie Lai, Arsalan Shahla, Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney speaks during a meeting with US President Donald Trump on the sidelines of the G7 Summit, in Kananaskis, Canada, on June 16. Photographer: Mark Schiefelbein/AP Photo

item.title: China Warns Iran-Israel Conflict May Spiral, Calls for Peace
item.description: China warned the Iran-Israel conflict may spread wider instability in the Middle East, with Foreign Minister Wang Yi reaching out to both countries as their days-old conflict shows no end in sight.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao
